FRS_Method: GPS CODE (PSEUDO RANGE) STANDARD POSITION (SA OFF)

_prev_prog_3.Description: The Risk Management Prevention Program for this facility is the OSHA required Process Safety Management documentation based on 29CFR1910.119.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
The H.C. Brill Company plant produces and distributes frozen un-iced, finished cakes and cookies.   The facility utilizes anhydrous ammonia as a refrigerant to maintain the proper temperature for storing product until distribution.  Anhydrous ammonia is an effective refrigerant that has been used for many years by most food processing facilities.  Ammonia is normally a gas at ambient temperatures but is handled as a gas liquefied under pressure.  The refrigeration system consists of a high pressure vessel, evaporators, compressors, piping and other refrigeration equipment.

Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies:   
H.C. Brill Company is committed to promoting safety for the plant, its employees and the surrounding area.  The facility is complying with OSHA's Process Safety Management Standard, Title 29 Code of Federal Regulations 1910.110 and EPA's Risk Management Program Title 40 CFR Part 68.  The purpose of these programs is to ensure that the refrigeration system is operated safely in order to prevent releases of ammonia from the system.  In addition, there programs serve to develop procedures to minimize releases in the event that they do occur and to outline appropriate emergency action steps to take in the event of a release.

Worst Case Release Scenario:  
EPA's "Risk Management Program Guidance for Ammonia Refrigeration" and the International Institute of Ammonia Refrigeration's Risk Management Guidelines were the primary documents used to develop the worst case release scenario.  The worst case release is one that is unlikely to occur.  The purpose of the worst care release analysis is to support a dialogue with the community on release prevention.  It is conservative analysis and is not to serve as a rational basis for the actual emergency response planning.

The worst case release scenario is the release of the largest quantity of ammonia from a vessel or process line failure that results in the greatest distance to a toxic endpoin

t.  The worst case release scenario for the refrigeration process is assumed to be a case where the total of ammonia in the high pressure vessel is released.  The release scenario was conducted assuming that the vessel was filled to capacity.  

The toxic endpoint used for this scenario must be where the ambient concentration of ammonia is 0.14 mg/L or less.  This endpoint is a concentration below which nearly all individuals could be exposed to for one hour without serious health effects.  Bases on Exhibit 4-4 in EPA's guidance, a release from the vessel would result in a situation where public receptors would be within the distance to the toxic endpoint.

Alternative Case Release Scenario:  
The alternative release scenario selected is one in which an ammonia relief rate discharges.  EPA's "Risk Management Program Guidance for Ammonia Refrigeration and the International Institute of Ammonia Refrigeration's Risk Management Guidelines were the primary documents used to develop the alternative release scenario.  The alternative release scenario is one that is more likely to occur than the worst case release scenario.

The alternative release scenario must meet two criteria:
1.   Must be more likely to occur that the worst case scenario, and
2.   Must reach an endpoint off site, unless no such criteria exist.

A relief valve discharge or a pipe leak has been determined as a likely alternative release scenario.  The toxic endpoint used for this scenario must be where the ambient concentration of ammonia is 0.14 mg/L or less.  Based on EPA's guidance, the alternative release scenario would not result in a situation where public receptors would be within the distance to the toxic endpoint.

Accidental Release Prevention Program:  As a part of the PSM program, H.C. Brill Company has established numerous programs that serve to prevent accidental releases of ammonia.  There programs include:
Process Safety Information
Process Hazard Analysis
Operating Procedures
Training
Me

chanical Integrity
Management of Change
Pre Startup Safety Review
Compliance Audits
Incident Investigation
Employee Participation
Hot Work Permits
Contractor Safety

Emergency Response Information:  As a part of the PSM Program,H.C. Brill Company maintains an Emergency Action Plan that was prepared in order to improve responsiveness to an emergency incident, and to increase the reliability of actions taken during an incident.  The plan includes all aspects of emergency response including adequate first aid and medical treatment, evacuations, notification of local emergency response agencies as well as the public.  In the event of an emergency involving the ammonia system, it is the policy of the facility to request assistance as necessary by calling 911.

Five-Year Accident History:  H.C. Brill Company has an excellent record of preventing accidental releases.  

Steps to Improve Safety: H.C. Brill Company is taking a hands on approach to enduring the safety of their employees and community.   H.C. Brill Company will operate and maintain the system in accordance with IIAR Guidance and will continue to implement its OSHA PSM Program in conjunction with the Risk Management Program.
